name: Matsue Castle Park Sakura
short_description: Cherry blossoms surrounding one of Japan's few remaining original castle towers.
description:
Matsue Castle, known as the 'Black Castle' or 'Plover Castle,' is one of only 12 original castle towers remaining in Japan. During the spring, the castle grounds transform as over 200 cherry trees, including Somei Yoshino and weeping cherry varieties, reach full bloom. The contrast between the dark, imposing wood of the castle and the delicate pink petals is a quintessential Japanese sight.

The park is designated as one of Japan's Top 100 Cherry Blossom spots. During the festival, the trees are illuminated at night, creating a 'yozakura' (night sakura) atmosphere. Visitors can also take boat tours around the Horikawa moat to see the blossoms from the water, passing under historic bridges while staying warm under the boat's kotatsu heaters.

name: Kintaikyo Bridge Sakura
short_description: Iconic five-arched wooden bridge framed by thousands of cherry trees.
description:
The Kintaikyo Bridge is an architectural marvel consisting of five wooden arches spanning the Nishiki River. In late March, approximately 3,000 cherry trees in the adjacent Kikko Park and along the riverbanks bloom, creating a pink frame for this historic structure. The bridge was originally built in 1673 and has been meticulously reconstructed over the centuries using traditional joinery methods without nails.

During the peak season, the area is a hub for 'hanami' (flower viewing) parties. The reflection of the illuminated arches and the cherry blossoms in the river at night is particularly famous. Visitors often enjoy local Iwakuni-zushi (pressed sushi) while wandering through the park, which also houses several samurai residences and museums.

name: Senkoji Park Sakura
short_description: Hilltop park offering panoramic views of the Seto Inland Sea through cherry blossoms.
description:
Located at the summit of Mt. Senkoji, this park offers one of the most famous views in Hiroshima Prefecture. Over 1,500 cherry trees cover the hillside, leading down toward the narrow Onomichi Channel and the islands of the Seto Inland Sea. The park is a primary stop for those exploring the town's famous 'Temple Walk.'

Highlights include the Senkoji Ropeway, which provides an aerial view of the pink canopy, and the 'Path of Literature,' where boulders are inscribed with poems by famous Japanese authors. The sight of the cherry blossoms against the backdrop of cranes in the local shipyards and the blue sea creates a unique blend of industrial and natural beauty.

name: Tsuyama Castle (Kakuzan Park)
short_description: Thousands of cherry trees blooming within the massive stone walls of a former fortress.
description:
Tsuyama Castle was once a massive complex with over 70 buildings, and although the main tower was dismantled in the 19th century, the impressive stone walls remain. Today, the site is known as Kakuzan Park and hosts over 1,000 cherry trees, making it Okayama's premier sakura destination. The sheer density of the trees creates a 'sea of blossoms' when viewed from the reconstructed watchtowers.

The Tsuyama Cherry Blossom Festival features tea ceremonies, taiko drum performances, and local food stalls. At night, the park is illuminated by lanterns, turning the castle ruins into a dreamlike landscape. The site is particularly favored by photographers for the way the pink petals contrast with the ancient gray stone masonry.

name: Utsubuki Park Sakura
short_description: A historic park at the foot of Mt. Utsubuki with thousands of cherry trees and azaleas.
description:
Utsubuki Park is widely considered the best cherry blossom spot in the San'in region. It features roughly 4,000 cherry trees of various types, including Somei Yoshino and double-petal varieties. The park was established in 1904 to commemorate a visit by the Crown Prince (later Emperor Taisho) and has since become a cherished local landmark.

The park is also famous for its azaleas, which bloom shortly after the cherry blossoms, extending the spring colors into May. During the festival, the 'Hagoromo' pond provides beautiful reflections of the illuminated trees. The park serves as a gateway to the Kurayoshi White Wall District, allowing visitors to combine flower viewing with a stroll through Edo-period warehouses.

name: Momijidani Park (Miyajima)
short_description: Vibrant autumn maple leaves in a valley on the sacred island of Miyajima.
description:
Momijidani Park, located at the base of Mt. Misen on Miyajima Island, is one of Japan's most celebrated autumn foliage spots. 'Momiji' means maple, and the park is home to around 700 trees that turn brilliant shades of crimson and orange in November. The park was originally landscaped in the Edo period when maple saplings were planted along the river.

The iconic red Momijibashi bridge at the park's entrance is a focal point for visitors and photographers. Beyond the bridge, walking paths wind through the forest toward the ropeway station, offering quiet spots to appreciate the 'koyo' (autumn colors) away from the crowds at Itsukushima Shrine. The island's wild deer are often seen resting under the colorful canopy.

name: Okayama Korakuen Garden (Autumn)
short_description: Stunning autumn colors in one of Japan's three finest traditional gardens.
description:
Korakuen is a 'daimyo' (feudal lord) garden completed in 1700 and is renowned for its spacious lawns and winding waterways. In November, the 'Chishio-no-mori' maple grove becomes the star attraction, with its leaves turning a deep red. The garden is designed as a 'strolling garden,' meaning the view changes with every step, incorporating Okayama Castle as 'borrowed scenery.'

Special autumn events often include the 'Genso Teien' (Garden of Dreams) illumination, where the garden is lit up after dark, and the traditional crane release. The reflection of the colored maples in the central Sawa-no-ike pond is a highlight, especially during the crisp, clear days of late autumn.

name: Mount Daisen Koyo
short_description: Dramatic autumn foliage on the slopes of the 'Mount Fuji of the West.'
description:
Mount Daisen is a volcanic peak that dominates the landscape of western Tottori. In autumn, its extensive beech forests turn a golden yellow, while maples provide splashes of red. The area around Daisen-ji Temple and the Kagikake Pass offers some of the most spectacular views, where the colorful forest meets the rugged, exposed rock of the mountain's southern face.

Peak foliage usually occurs from late October to early November. Visitors can hike the various trails or take the Daisen Loop Bus to different viewpoints. The Daisen-ji temple complex also holds a fall festival with evening illuminations of the temple gates and surrounding trees, emphasizing the spiritual connection between the mountain and the changing seasons.

name: Yushien Garden Autumn Illumination
short_description: Spectacular night light-up of maples and peonies on Daikonshima Island.
description:
Yushien is a traditional Japanese garden famous for its peonies, but its autumn foliage and night illuminations are equally renowned. Located on Daikonshima Island in Lake Nakaumi, the garden features over 300 maple trees. In November, the garden hosts a massive illumination event that uses cutting-edge lighting and projection mapping to enhance the natural colors of the leaves.

The reflection of illuminated red maples in the garden's pond is a signature sight. Even after the leaves fall, the garden transitions into a winter illumination theme, making it a major seasonal attraction for the San'in region. The indoor peony house allows visitors to see 'winter peonies' blooming even in the cold, protected by traditional straw mats.

name: Chomonkyo Gorge Koyo
short_description: Scenic riverside walking trail through a canyon filled with autumn colors.
description:
Chomonkyo is a picturesque gorge along the Abu River, designated as a Place of Scenic Beauty. A 5.5-kilometer walking trail follows the river, passing through tunnels and over bridges, with the steep valley walls covered in maples and zelkova trees. In autumn, the gorge becomes a tunnel of red and orange foliage reflected in the clear river water.

The trail is relatively flat and accessible, making it popular for families and casual hikers. Local specialties like 'ayuzushi' (sweetfish sushi) and grilled river fish are sold at the entrance and exit points. The gorge is particularly famous for its 'Meiji-era' atmosphere, having been a popular destination for poets and painters since the late 19th century.

name: Saidaiji Temple Eyo (Naked Festival)
short_description: Thousands of men in loincloths compete for sacred sticks in this high-energy ritual.
description:
One of Japan's most eccentric and famous festivals, Saidaiji Eyo has a history dating back over 500 years. On the third Saturday of February, roughly 10,000 men dressed only in 'fundoshi' (loincloths) gather at Saidaiji Kannon-in Temple. After purifying themselves in cold water, they crowd into the temple hall to wait for the priest to drop two sacred 'shingi' sticks into the crowd from a high window.

The resulting scramble is a display of strength and endurance, as the men believe that whoever secures the sticks and thrusts them into a box of rice will be blessed with a year of good luck. The festival is a designated Important Intangible Folk Cultural Property. While the main event is for participants, tens of thousands of spectators gather to watch the ritual and enjoy the festive atmosphere and food stalls.

name: Hiroshima Flower Festival
short_description: One of Japan's largest Golden Week festivals, featuring parades and flower displays.
description:
Held annually from May 3rd to 5th, the Hiroshima Flower Festival attracts over 1.6 million visitors. The festival was established in 1977 with the themes of 'Peace,' 'Flowers,' and 'Music.' It takes place along Peace Boulevard (Heiwa-dori) and in the Peace Memorial Park, which is filled with vibrant floral displays and the 'Flower Tower' symbol.

The event kicks off with a massive parade featuring thousands of dancers and performers. There are dozens of stages throughout the city hosting live music, traditional performances, and international cultural exchanges. The festival culminates in the 'Peace Flower' ceremony, reinforcing Hiroshima's identity as a city of peace and renewal.

name: Shimonoseki Kaikyo Festival
short_description: A grand historical reenactment of the Battle of Dan-no-ura and samurai culture.
description:
Held from May 2nd to 4th, this festival commemorates the historic events that took place in the Kanmon Straits. The highlight is the 'Senteisai' ceremony, where 'tayū' (high-ranking courtesans) in elaborate traditional dress walk across a wooden bridge at Akama Shrine in a unique, slow-motion gait. This ritual honors the child Emperor Antoku, who perished in the Battle of Dan-no-ura in 1185.

Other events include a naval parade of boats reenacting the battle between the Genji and Heike clans and a 'samurai parade' through the city streets. The festival offers a deep dive into Japan's transition from the Heian to the Kamakura period and provides a stunning visual spectacle against the backdrop of the modern Kanmon Bridge.

name: Izumo Taisha Kamiari Festival
short_description: The gathering of all Japanese Shinto deities at Izumo's Great Shrine.
description:
According to Japanese mythology, in the tenth month of the lunar calendar (usually November), all eight million Shinto deities leave their shrines across Japan to gather at Izumo Taisha for a week of meetings. While the rest of Japan calls this month 'Kannazuki' (Month of No Gods), Izumo calls it 'Kamiarizuki' (Month of Gods Present).

During this time, several solemn rituals are held, including the 'Kami-mukaesai' (Welcoming the Gods) at Inasa Beach and the week-long 'Kamiari-sai' at the shrine. It is believed the gods meet to decide the 'en-musubi' (fateful connections and relationships) for the coming year. While many rituals are private, the atmosphere at the shrine is electric, with special charms and foods available for the thousands of pilgrims who visit.

name: Tottori Shan-shan Festival
short_description: A massive umbrella dance festival involving thousands of performers.
description:
Held in mid-August, the Shan-shan Festival is Tottori's largest summer event. The name 'Shan-shan' comes from the sound of water boiling in the city's hot springs and the sound of bells ringing on the umbrellas. The festival's centerpiece is the 'Kasa Odori' (Umbrella Dance), where over 4,000 participants dance through the streets carrying umbrellas decorated with bells and long strips of silver paper.

The dance is a modern adaptation of a traditional rain-making ritual. The sight of thousands of colorful umbrellas spinning in unison is mesmerizing. The festival also includes a large fireworks display over the Sendai River. It has been recognized by the Guinness World Records for the largest simultaneous umbrella dance.

name: Hiroshima Dreamination
short_description: A winter wonderland of lights along Hiroshima's main boulevard.
description:
From mid-November to early January, Hiroshima's Peace Boulevard (Heiwa-dori) is transformed into a fantasy world by over 1.4 million LED lights. The theme is 'A Fairytale Land,' featuring massive light sculptures of castles, dragons, pirate ships, and forests. It is one of the largest winter illumination events in Western Japan.

The displays are designed to be interactive, with many sculptures providing perfect photo opportunities for families and couples. The event was started to bring cheer and light to the city during the cold winter months and has grown into a major tourism draw. The 'Peace Fire' at the end of the boulevard serves as a reminder of the city's core message amidst the festive celebration.

name: Tottori Hana-kairo Illumination
short_description: One of Japan's largest flower parks lit up with millions of winter lights.
description:
The Tottori Prefectural Flower Park (Hana-kairo) hosts a spectacular winter illumination from mid-November to mid-January. Over 1.4 million lights are used to decorate the park's 50 hectares, including its massive glass greenhouse and circular covered walkway. The event combines the beauty of winter flowers, such as pansies and violas, with elaborate light designs.

A highlight is the nightly fireworks display that takes place during the peak of the illumination season. The park's location offers a stunning view of Mount Daisen, which is often snow-capped during the winter. The 'Flower Dome' provides a warm indoor space to enjoy floral displays even on the coldest nights.

name: Shunan Tree Festival
short_description: Winter lights featuring candle-shaped illuminations and a 'Night View Heritage' site.
description:
The Shunan Tree Festival is a signature winter event in Yamaguchi Prefecture, recognized as a 'Japan Night View Heritage' site. The area around Tokuyama Station and along the city's main streets is decorated with roughly 700,000 LED bulbs. The highlight is the 'Candle Stream,' where candle-shaped lights are arranged to create a warm, flickering glow throughout the urban center.

The festival includes a 'Fantastic Night' event with stage performances and food stalls. The industrial background of Shunan, known for its factories, creates a unique contrast with the delicate fairy lights. It is a popular spot for winter 'factory night view' enthusiasts who come to see the city's dual identity as an industrial hub and a land of winter lights.

name: Bihoku Illumination
short_description: Rustic and grand winter light display in the hilly Bihoku region.
description:
National Bihoku Hillside Park hosts one of Hiroshima's most popular winter events. Unlike urban illuminations, this event utilizes the park's sprawling natural terrain, incorporating forests, ponds, and traditional farmhouses into the light designs. The theme changes annually, often focusing on Japanese folklore or seasonal beauty.

Visitors can enjoy hot local snacks while walking through the light tunnels and large-scale installations. The 'Starlight Fireworks' are a recurring feature on weekends. Because it is located in the northern, mountainous part of the prefecture, it is not uncommon for the lights to be blanketed in a layer of snow, making for a truly magical winter experience.

name: Matsue Suigo Festival
short_description: One of Western Japan's largest lakeside fireworks displays on Lake Shinji.
description:
The Suigo Festival is the premier summer event in the 'Water City' of Matsue. Held over a weekend in early August, the festival culminates in a massive fireworks display over the waters of Lake Shinji. Around 10,000 fireworks are launched, including large-scale shells that illuminate the entire lake and the famous sunset silhouette of Yomegashima Island.

The festival also features traditional boat parades, live music on stages along the shore, and hundreds of food stalls. It is a celebration of Matsue's connection to its lakes and rivers. Locals and tourists alike wear yukata and gather on the lakeside parks hours in advance to secure a spot for the spectacular show.

name: Hofu Tenmangu Gojinko-sai
short_description: The 'Hadakabo' (Naked) Festival of Hofu, featuring a wild shrine procession.
description:
Held on the fourth Saturday of November, this is one of the most dynamic and historic festivals in Yamaguchi. It commemorates the arrival of Sugawara no Michizane, the deity of learning, at Hofu. Thousands of men dressed in white 'hadakabo' robes carry massive portable shrines (mikoshi) down the steep stone steps of the Hofu Tenmangu Shrine.

The procession is known for its intensity and speed, as the participants shout 'Brother! Brother!' while navigating the heavy shrines through the crowds. It is considered one of the three major Tenmangu festivals in Japan. The sight of the white-clad participants against the backdrop of the oldest Tenmangu shrine in the country is a powerful display of local faith and energy.

name: Okutsu Valley Koyo
short_description: A three-kilometer gorge famous for its potholes and vivid maple leaves.
description:
Okutsu Valley is a premier autumn destination in northern Okayama. The Yoshino River has carved a dramatic valley here, famous for its 'potholes'—circular holes in the riverbed rocks created by swirling water and stones. In November, the surrounding maple trees turn a brilliant red, which contrasts beautifully with the white water and dark rocks.

A walking trail allows visitors to view the 'Eight Views of Okutsu,' including several waterfalls and unique rock formations. The area is also famous for the Okutsu Onsen hot spring resort nearby, where visitors can enjoy a 'wash dance' performance by local women at the riverside baths. The combination of autumn colors and steaming hot springs makes it a classic Japanese fall getaway.

name: Iwami Ginzan Silver Mine (Autumn)
short_description: UNESCO World Heritage silver mine town surrounded by autumn mountains.
description:
Iwami Ginzan was one of the world's leading silver mines from the 16th to the 20th century. Today, the town of Omori and the mine shafts are part of a UNESCO World Heritage site. In autumn, the forested mountains surrounding the historic town turn deep shades of red and gold, making a walk through the preserved samurai and merchant districts particularly scenic.

Visitors can explore the Ryugenji Mabu mine shaft and then walk back to town along a riverside path under the autumn canopy. The temple of Rakanji, with its 500 stone statues of Arhats, is a highlight in the fall when the temple grounds are covered in maple leaves. The site offers a peaceful, historical atmosphere far removed from the busy modern cities.

name: Hikawa Teibo Sakura
short_description: A 2-kilometer tunnel of cherry blossoms along the Hii River.
description:
The Hikawa Teibo (Hii River Embankment) is one of the most famous sakura spots in the San'in region. Approximately 800 cherry trees line the riverbank for two kilometers, creating a literal tunnel of pink flowers that visitors can walk through. The spot is particularly famous for its 'Somei Yoshino' trees, which were planted in the early Showa era.

At night, the trees are lit up with traditional lanterns, creating a romantic and nostalgic atmosphere. The area is also linked to the Japanese legend of Yamata-no-Orochi (the eight-headed serpent), as the Hii River is said to be the site where the deity Susanoo defeated the beast. The combination of natural beauty and deep mythological roots makes it a significant cultural site.

name: Okayama Korakuen Genso Teien
short_description: Special night light-up events in the historic Korakuen Garden.
description:
While Korakuen is beautiful year-round, the 'Genso Teien' (Garden of Dreams) illumination events are a seasonal highlight, typically held in August and November. During these periods, the garden stays open late, and the paths, ponds, and groves are illuminated with thousands of candles and LED lights. The nearby Okayama Castle is also lit up, serving as a dramatic backdrop.

The summer event focuses on providing a 'cool' evening atmosphere with bamboo lanterns and wind chimes, while the autumn event highlights the changing colors of the maple leaves. Traditional music performances and tea ceremonies are often held in the garden's historic buildings, offering visitors a rare chance to experience the daimyo-style garden in a magical night-time setting.
